I think there's another aspect of the physical eye that's important.  Your cones don't send their signals directly to the brain.  Instead, they're combined in a clever way beforehand.  One nerve carries the ratio of red to green, and another nerve carries the ratio of red AND green - yellow - to blue.  And the total amount of light is detected by your rods and sent using another nerve.  So your eye is sending the total plus the blue ratio, plus the green ratio of the rest.  That's why yellow seems like a real color.

I get so annoyed at that old school color wheel where they call R Y B the primaries. The eye receptors are focused on wavelengths much more close to R G B.  And folks making printers and televisions have understood this for so many years-- C M Y are the primaries of the subtractive model and R G B are the primaries of the additive model; for example, cyan is green plus blue, or white minus red. Schools have been stuck on 18th century bunkum.

Actually, light color mixing occurs essentially the same way as pigment color mixing. Mixing pure red and green pigment should produce yellow. The only problem is that while colors of light get lighter as they are mixed, colors of pigment get darker as they are mixed. Thus, mixing pure red and green pigment will produce a dark yellow, which is a brownish color. This is also why mixing red and blue pigment gives a dark, often unsightly purple instead of a bright one. Another interesting fact is that while the primary colors of light are red, green, and blue, and the secondary colors are cyan, magenta and yellow, with pigment the primary and secondary colors are reversed. This is demonstrated with printers, which use magenta, yellow and cyan to make every hue. The classic color system with red, yellow and blue is just plain wrong.

Nicely done. I would suggest, though, that we not speak of red light. Or blue light.

Light does not have color. Rather, color exists only in our perception. So when we speak of the "colors" of the visible light spectrum we should call them out by wavelength.

So-called "yellow" light has a wavelength of around 590 nm. Shine that on your eye and you'll call it yellow. But it's not yellow light! It's yellow perception.

You demonstrated that shining 700 nm so-called "red" light and 500 nm so-called "green" light on the eye and you'll call it yellow. Again, it's not yellow light! It's yellow perception.

Best explanation I've seen. I finally get it! Thanks!

The cones in your eyes seeing red, green, and blue is a common misconception, assuming that they add in the same way as a computer monitor's primaries.
In reality, the peak wavelengths of the cones are an orangey yellow, green, and kind of bluish violet. Your eyes perceive colours by both the additive processes, and also by opposition. both red and a yellow will have a similar effect on the orangey cones in your eyes, but your brain can tell the difference because the red light will only trigger the orangey cones, and the yellow light will also have a weak effect on the green cones.
What's interesting about this, is that the sensitivities overlap, so can't produce all of the colors you see using primaries that match the peak wavelengths of the cones,

For the title NO

Physics Girl, you know it's an over-simplification to say the cones are red, green, and blue, right? Our eyes are not as simple as an RGB monitor. Your diagram showed that these are actually short, medium, and long wave receptors that detect a range of frequencies. In fact, look again at the video, the "red cone" actually peaks around yellow (so in that sense it's more of a "yellow cone" than red). Scientists more correctly call them S, M, and L cones. In addition, there are other cells called double-opponent cells that play a role in color vision.

Well, yeah. Basic colour theory on additive and subractive colours.

Red and green are complimentary contrasts, meaning they're on opposite sides of the colour wheel. When you use pigments, let's say paint, to mix opposite colours, you get brown or brownish earth colours. That is subtractive mixing of colours, when the pigment absorbs LESS light the more different colours you mix in.

But with lamps, spotlights or luminary screens, you ADD light, meaning the colour quality won't travel into dark or blackness, but change its colour while maintaing bright and clean.

actually, the primary paint colours are magenta, cyan, and yellow. look at a printer and its colour cartridges. if you mix those three colours, you get black. that's why when you were in elementary school and your teacher gave you crimson red, yellow, and ultramarine blue paint you always got those ugly muddy colours instead of bright green or purple. the reason why we were taught that the primary colours were red, yellow, and blue is because a long time ago it was hard to obtain some pigments like magenta and cyan. i think that now that we know, teachers should be teaching kids that the primary colours are magenta, yellow, and cyan.

for those who don't know why they only see red or blue:
it's because the frames per second you're watching the video in is too low which is most likely 30 fps. if the colors are oscillating at 60 oscillations per second aka 60 fps, but you're watching at only 30 fps(standard) you'll only see every other oscillation and see only one color

at 60fps you'd see:
RBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRBRB

but at 30fps you only see:
R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_R_
the frames are skipping

It is interest to think, red and green light make us see yellow, but actual yellow light (split from a prism for example) also stimulates our red and green cones the same way and makes us see yellow, so you can't actually tell whether you are "seeing" yellow or red and green light together (unless you can get close enough to make out individual pigment cells like in a screen). For example is a banana reflecting actual yellow light or red and green light together, you can't know unless you know what the actual pigments are in a banana.

for anyone who's still confused, this might help you understand how paint is different from light. when light hits paint, all other colors are absorbed into the material except for the one shade (yellow, for say), which is reflected back and into our eyes. If you add blue paint to yellow paint, it becomes green paint. this is called subtractive mixing (subtractive as in light is absorbed by the paint, hence the "subtraction" of colors). Light, however, is different. Adding two colors of light together is called additive mixing. It's called additive mixing because combining (adding) the two lights creates a different color light. there's no material for this light to be absorbed (subtracted) into since light doesn't absorb light. it just blends together. For paint, the paint is absorbing light and reflecting one shade of light.

A big problem is the term "colors". Color is a property of light. In art class, they should use the term "pigments". Mixing pigments, or paints, is a subtractive process. Different layers of pigments prevent certain wavelengths of light from being reflected back to your eye. Mixing colors, the properties of light that you see, using lights is an additive process and your eye sees them as a combination of the two colors' wavelengths.

"all 3 cones should now get excited. but blue was the only one that wasn't dulled over time, so it will send a stronger signal to your brain. and your brain will tell you "there's blue light", even when there's not".

Actually, the end of this statement is false. There IS blue light there, because the monitor only produces red, green and blue light. White is the illusion, not blue. So it's not that dulling the red and green cones is producing the illusion of blue, rather dulling the red and green cones is weakening the illusion of white and allowing us to see the blue light that is in fact there.

Basically what this video demonstrates is that there are two color systems in nature. One being the subtractive system and the other being the additive system. With the subtractive system, pigments that are combined actually create darker colors because they subtract their wavelengths, hence resulting in darker colors. things that use this system are pretty much everything in the world such as paint/dyes, tv/computer screens etc. and the additive system is pretty much the opposite where if you combine light they add up their wavelengths to create a final color wavelength, pure white. Hopefully this clears up some confusion

Red and green mixed together in equal proportions always produce a yellow colour, even when done with paint instead of light. The trouble with paint is that it produces LOW LUMINOSITY yellow... In other words it is yellow with a lot of black in it, a colour we usually call "brown."

The very first white LEDs were really blue with a phosphor that fluoresced yellow creating white light with two complementary colors. Unfortunately things illuminated by them didn't show their true color and they were soon phased out. Current white LEDs again start with blue light but have two phosphors, red and green, to give more faithful color reproduction.

Sadly, a lot of falsehoods being perpetuated as usually happens when people talk about color.

First of all, the cones aren't red, green and blue. That would be the most common display technology. The cones are more correctly called LMS or long, medium and short wavelength. Cones can't normally be activated in isolation, so a cone doesn't correspond to any normal color. Devising a way to do it such as by tiring only certain cones (which was mentioned in the video but for a different purpose) produces so-called imaginary colors. Short of exploiting such limitations in the visual system, you could for example note the color of light at the wavelength where the response of a particular cone peaks. Then S=blue, M=bluish green, L=yellowish green.

Yellow isn't defined to be monochromatic light at a wavelength of 580 nm. It's a percept based on the integration of multiple kinds of cones. There are many ways to produce a particular color. A blend of multiple wavelengths only constrains saturation. We aren't bipedal spectrometers! Besides, how would you define something like white or purple? Neither can be produced by any single wavelength. A mix of red and green run through a low-pass filter or any kind of optical mixing process really IS yellow.

There are some variations in pigments between people. There's also how aging yellows the lens. This is why there are subtle variations between people who would all be considered to have normal color vision. It's generally close enough that most of us would agree for the most part.

Color wheels get really messy. Additive color is easy: simply linear combinations, however many dimensions you're using to evaluate colors. The gamut is always a nice convex polytope. Subtractive color (which is a bit of a misnomer) is much trickier because interactions across the entire spectrum matter. You can't simply reduce it to a few channels to model it accurately. Reflection and absorption have different results, too. This is why an RGB monitor can easily produce white but CMY ink can't produce proper black. And then in printing there's halftone patterns, dot gain, etc.

Tetrachromacy doesn't seem to happen in a meaningful way in humans. There are some numbers going around but very few have demonstrated increased discrimination in practice. Interestingly, they tend to be women who would've been like men with color vision deficiency if not for their additional X chromosome. The pigment that normally reduces color discrimination is now just an additional pigment.

Nice one - I hate it, when students mistakenly and stubbornly tries to tell me, that the primary colors are red, yellow and blue. First: They're not. Not in any color space involving human vision. In almost all of these sensory illusions the relaxation time of the sensory cells plays an important role. For example at 3:23, even though you are not flashing red and cyan screens alternately, when you switch from red to cyan one can still see white for a fraction of a second. Because the signal from the red cone hasn't died off when the other cones register cyan.

Actually, the primary colors of pigment are cyan, yellow, and magenta--the secondary colors of light. If you mix red and green pigment, you get this:
red: absorbs blue and green
green: absorbs blue and red
mixed: absorbs green, red, and strongly absorbs blue

This yields "brown" which is just a yellowish grey. True brown has more red than green and more green than blue, but has all three. But why do we name it brown when we do not recognize the other five similar color combinations? Why do we not consider the color with more green than blue, and more blue than red, but with all three, to be a color warranting its own name? We usually just refer to it as a shade of green or teal, or a brownish teal or a greyish teal, or an unsaturated green or teal. But in truth, brown is just a greyish or unsaturated red-orange.

If you mix the three primary pigment colors magenta, cyan, and yellow together, it yields black. Now most of our pigments are not a high enough quality and the color you get from mixing them will be close to black but visibly different. This is why CMYK printers use four toner colors: yellow, cyan, magenta, and a black or key toner to enhance the blackness of fully mixed yellow, cyan, and magenta.
that's so cool

Pigment = subtractive color, combining the primaries (Magenta, Cyan, Yellow) yields black, as all wavelengths are absorbed.
Light = Additive color, combining the primaries (Red, Green, Blue) yields white, as all wavelengths are emitted/reflected.

This is why we have to white balance cameras whenever there's a lighting change.  (I'm a TV cameraman, by the way.)  When there's a change in lighting, like going from incandescent to fluorescent, the room is being hit with a slightly bluer light.  Our eyes adjust to this change so it all looks normal to us, but if the camera isn't properly white balanced, it just records everything as is.  Then you play back the video and wonder why everything looks tinted blue.  This is basically what happened with that blue dress that went viral a few months ago.

We don’t literally have red cones but yellow cones instead.
Our cones are specialized in blue (S type), green (M type) and yellow (L type).

You said we see in Blue, Green and Red... but in the graphic you use, it's clearly showing we see in Blue, Green and Yellow.
In fact, a lot of biologists admit that what we call Red cones should rather be called Yellow cones.
Technically speaking, some animals have true Red cones, some of them can even see more than three colors.

For humans, Red is just borderline Yellow...
But a TV can't make us see Red by projecting massive Yellow... because Green cones will be activited too...
So in fact the problem is that we dont have Red cones... but Yellow cones instead... wich are too close to Green ones.
The TV dodge that using red LED to make red, and green and red LED to make yellow.

So, it appear to me that you missed the central point.
Human eyes are very bad at seeing Red... because Nature is Blue sky and Green/Yellowish leaves !
If we had Red cones, we can actually see a bit of infra-red, which is not the case.
Instead we have Yellow cones... and are very good at seeing Yellow.
That is why some TV added Yellow LED !!
Ok most TV use two colors to make Yellow... but a TV also use two color for Cyan, Purple... and even three for Brown.
But no TV brand offers you to add Cyan, Purple and Brown LED.

In color theory it is called additive mixing when you are using light and moving something towards white in perception and subtractive when moving toward black. Also this is relates to image file types being CMYK (Cyan Magenta Yellow and BlacK) or RGB (Red Green and Blue). When printing the ink behaves subtractively (gets darker) so you want to start with bright colors of ink and maybe tint them darker with black to get a good illusion, but if the image is intended to go on screen it's encoded in red green and blue so it matches up with the pixels on screen (additive color).

Additive color : mixing takes you towards WHITE (R+G=Y)
Additive color mixing is what happens with light and screen/monitors and this spinning disc. R G B are primary colors.

Subtractive color : mixing takes you towards BLACK (R+G=Br)
Subtractive color mixing is what happens with art, printing press and this paint. R Y B (CMYK) are primary colors.

Just to nitpick a bit - latency of LCD screens (on which most of us will probably be viewing this) also contributes to the mixing of rapidly flashing colors. Crystals take some time to assume a new state (new color for the pixel). Like if you have a ball rolling inside a closed off tube and you're quickly leaning the tube left and right alternatively, the ball will spend much of its time traveling and might not even have the time to reach the endpoints before rolling to the other side. Thus, the color we're seeing leans a bit towards a light gray even before our human perception factors in (because the pixels "travel" towards red and cyan, maybe not even reaching them fully on slower screens). Not by much on modern LCDs, but it is a factor. Fun fact: older LCD screens were much slower and often black and white screens were "abused" this way to achieve different shades of gray (by flashing black and white at different speeds), like on the original Game Boy.

Great video.  If our eyes had receptors for more colors, then making LCD displays for computer monitors, TVs, and cell phones would be far more difficult.  True yellow light is a different frequency of light, not a combination of the red frequency and green frequency.  Fortunately for LCD manufacturers, our eyes can't tell the difference.

You should have discussed how the RGY model of paint colours is not very scientific. Your printer uses yellow, magenta and cyan to make every colour, and that model works exactly the opposite of light mixing. (for example mixing the primaries or compliments gives black, rather than brown) You should note that the under this model, primaries of light are the compliments of the primaries of pigment.

The by far easiest way to learn how complimentary colors work is to use RGB values for five minutes. 255,255,255 is white, 0,0,0 is black, 150,150,150 is gray, 0,255,255 is cyan, 255,0,255 is yellow, and 255,255,0 is magenta.
Since monitors (and computers) use only the three colors we have cones for, this leads to RGB being very intuitive after learning the basic concept of it.
